bookmarks.note: NB: Citizens is the US and Britain are forbidden by law to buy or own monetary gold.

Chairman of the federal reserve says that the US will continue selling gold at $35/oz until the last bar. After Britain devalues the currency, President [Lyndon B.] Johnson reiterates this. But speculators begin buying gold, leading to high demand in Paris, Zurich, and other financial centers, and most particularly in London, where people began to talk about the London gold rush. Orders came from everywhere, amounting to $50m.
Gold at $35/oz.
Technical strength = caused by short sellers buying back the security to cash in their profits (or shorts being burned causing a short squeeze), and is temporary
Lol. The string of competitive devaluations -> devaluation of the dollar in relation to gold -> worldwide monetary chaos -> and perhaps a world depression
(What are) “Gnomes of Zurich”?
How the federal reserve preemptively attacked the anti-pound speculators
1964 sterling pound crisis
“...they would gladly consider the matter” lol

US NY Fed contains gold bars for other countries in the world. Fort Knox contains US gold reserves. If the dollar drops as other countries sell dollars for gold or their own currencies, causing the US to lose gold and causing the other currency to increase with respect to the USD (and other currencies), if it drops low enough and we lose enough gold (i.e. our gold reserve drops to an unacceptably low level), the US would have to break its promise: either lower the value of USD compared to gold (moving us from the gold standard), or or even to stop selling gold entirely. Either actions is in effect a devaluation... and a devaluation of the USD is the only potential devaluation that would have a more drastic effect than the GBP devaluation did
“the mire of cupidity”

LOL. By not including the Latex company as a defendant, BF Goodrich had effectively precluded its ability to win the case. The defendant was the scientist, and there was no plan from HIS side to give away trade secrets

“I’m Russell Watson, a reporter for the Wall Street Journal!” - I can use this quote in my life

How to get in somewhere: act like you belong, know where you’re going, and just ask how to get there. People will help you. If someone asks you “why?” well, we’ll cross that bridge when we get to it

Elon Musk’s bulletproof glass on his cybertruck is hardly the first example of design failures during presentations. The Xerox 914 (version 2) blew a generator instead of making a copy when Wilson first tried to demo it in London

But apparently the Merrill Lynch newswire receives PRs on its ticker before the Dow

In the Texas drilling case, the SEC alleges that the appearance of a PR on the Dow Jones broad (?) tape is the first time one can buy on information (i.e. the point at which it ceases to be inside information). Meaning? This is the place to look for “first” news. Of course, I can then try to go back even further into actually digging through a company, but this is usually enough
Why do they need this water to drill?
80,000 persons, mostly lawyers/accountants/former IRS employees who hold official cards entitling them to hold positions as tax advisor. Any can legally perform taxes for others

Virtually necessary to seek professional help to minimize taxes legally. And since first rate advice is expensive and inability supply, rich have an advantage. And fees for tax advice are themselves deductible. So using paid tax advisors (“practitioners”) saves money compared to the free tax-evasion advice provided by the IRS due to conflict of interest

“Gifts of appreciated securities, industrial property, leases, royalties, jewelry, antiques, stock options, residences, life insurance, and inventory items, and through the use of trusts” can be used for tax savings
Greater Tax Savings: A Constructive Approach by Princeton. Harvard and Yale have similar booklets
How to donate: sell securities to the 501c3 at cost, so all appreciation in value of the security is fully deductible. See Princeton’s book
Why there is a tax advantage to buying an oil well, regardless of whether you need it
Pennsylvania congressman upon Grover Cleveland’s suggestion to create an income tax: “a tax so odious, that no other administration ever dared to impose it except in times of war”
Mark Twain upon paying his first income tax: “I have never felt so important before in my life!”
I.E. you can’t be too perfect without risking rejection. The same principle that psychologists noticed later. The car needed at least some flaw for consumers to accept it
